author: Bob Hertzel For the Times West Virginian
title: WVU offense getting ‘pretty close’
text:
Posted: Wednesday, October 21, 2015 3:45 am WVU offense getting ‘pretty close’ By Bob Hertzel For the Times West Virginian Times West Virginian 
MORGANTOWN — In the aftermath of last Saturday’s 62-38 debacle in Waco, Texas, Dana Holgorsen admitted that he knew his team could not outscore Baylor. 
Not that that was breaking news, considering the Bears have the most potent offense in all of college football ... and not just by a smidgen, either. 
The disappointing thing is, Holgorsen says that his offense is “pretty close to where I thought we’d be” coming into the season. 
This well may be true, but somehow it seemed that there was far more optimism about the offense as the season opened than its position at present would indicate, standing sixth in nearly all major statistics save for rushing yardage, where its third-place position is more a reflection of it being forced to run more often due to a faulty passing game than an excellence at running the ball. 
That, one surmises, comes from a 4.3 yards per carry average, which ranks — yes — sixth in the league. 
Holgorsen’s tune was that he had a solid, if not spectacular, quarterback in Skyler Howard, strong running backs in Wendell Smallwood and Rushel Shell, a decent line anchored by maybe the best center in the league in Tyler Orlosky and speedy, if unproven, wide receivers. 
And when they came out in the opening game and showed so much promise, much of the concern seemed to evaporate. 
But now Holgorsen understands that he doesn’t have a contender on his hands — an 0-3 start in the conference tends to do that to you — and is now judging his team by its progress rather than by its results. 
“Our deal from the beginning has been just keep getting better,” Holgorsen said. “Lot of youth, lot of new players, lot of inexperience — just keep getting better. And I think we are. We’re on track. We need to continue that path.” 
It turns out that other than Shelton Gibson, who is emerging as a potential star, none of his receivers have risen to levels he would have hoped coming into the year, and the depth has been so shallow as having to take quarterback David Sills and use him at receiver this past week and having him make major contributions. 
Gibson’s play has been spectacular at times. 
“No. 1 for us is getting really close,” Holgorsen said of Gibson, who caught a 70-yard touchdown pass and returned a kickoff 100 yards for a second TD. “We’ve got to get the other guys to continue to develop, continue to mature, continue to build confidence. 
“We’re not there yet, but we’re going to get there pretty quick.” 
No one doubts Holgorsen when he makes that prediction, as he has created top-line receivers wherever he has been, and with Jovon Durante, Devonte Mathis, Gary Jennings and Ka’Raun White to work with along with Sills, he has no shortage of talent to develop. 
White, a junior college transfer, is the most intriguing, as he is a big body and the brother of last year’s All-American wide receiver Kevin White. He came in late, so naturally he figured to be a late bloomer but got his feet wet last week. 
“Ka’Raun has been on campus since June,” Holgorsen said, noting he missed spring ball. “Kevin was on campus for a year before things started clicking. I’m not comparing the two. I won’t.” 
NOTES: Holgorsen called CB Terrell Chestnut day-to-day with a shoulder injury. He has had a lot of problems with his shoulders and will need the extra time. The injury list is growing. LT Yodny Cajuste was “banged up” in the game and will rest this week. Orlosky “could hardly walk out there” and also will rest this week. And Holgorsen defended the restricted playing time he has given RB Wendell Smallwood, saying he had not practiced the last two weeks and those who questioned his lack of carries were off base. And finally the fall-off in production from last year’s Lou Groza Award finalist PK Josh Lambert is due from a preseason injury that lingered and then being under the weather the past couple weeks. 
Follow Bob Hertzel on Twitter @bhertzel.
